Dye
Some take Lapathium acutum maius, which seems to be rhapontic rhubarb or "vinette", and using the root, which is yellow in summer, they dye threads and similar things.
p040r_2
Aqua fortis
For four pounds of aqua fortis matter that is in the retort, some use four ounces of common water in the container, which is better than putting it into the retort. The alum is dried out and calcined so that the water doesn't have as many impurities. Many do it without drying out the alum.
p040r_3
Vinegar
It is widely accepted that heating the mineral salt that looks like a block of marble and is called Cardona salt in Catalonia and on Spain's borders, until it becomes red hot and throwing it red hot or quite hot in wine, turns it into very good vinegar. Some make it with water poured on pomace that has soured after being pressed by grape pickers, but it will not keep and spoils in hot and stormy weather.
p040r_4
"Vermeilles" buttons
Because "vermeilles" resist fire, they are cut into lozenges and flat on one side, next they are joined together in a star shape with a paste of ground enamel, which is then melted and the enamel is gilt with gold leaf and then reheated.
p040r_5
Grottos
To fill any empty place that cannot be hung with rocks, one puts a piece of thick parchment close to the fire, which retracts and crumples. Next it is painted with distemper, then in oil, and then affixed.
